entry.title: Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products
entry.content:
In my earlier 2 blogs I have talked about overview of SAP BDC and its key features.

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

In this blog we will continue to deep dive in SAP BDC key feature Data Products.

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products

What are Data products in SAP BDC?

Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud serve as a standardized and efficient way to share and consume data across applications and domains. They enable analytic scenarios, AI applications, and facilitate data integration while being optimized for intensive reads. Managed with a product mindset, they are supported by high-quality metadata and governed by decentralized ownership principles.

Data Product is a grouping concept that carries the relevant metadata to describe the dataset and its data qualities. It may consists of multiple objects.

A data product is a self-contained set of tables that has data exposed for consumption outside the producing application or service via APIs.

SAP applications such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud produce data products that can be consumed in SAP Datasphere via SAP Business Data Cloud data packages. Data products are also included in and provide the data for consumption by SAP Business Data Cloud intelligent applications.

A Data Product itself is not directly consumable, but it exposes data through output ports, which can be implemented as APIs or events.

A data product provides a predefined and stable structure and also the inbound and outbound interfaces for source system extraction and end tool consumption.

Data products are created in and only available in SAP Datasphere.

Basically, a Data product acts like a Datasource that can, not-only pull data from your sources but also has the required structure to store it, load capabilities and can help consume this data across various intelligent applications.

When an Intelligent Application is installed, it often creates one or more Data Products by pulling in raw business data from source systems, transforming and organizing it during the setup process. During this process the data extraction, harmonization, and integration is taken care by Data products.

 

Key Objectives‚Äã

  1. Efficient Data Sharing Across Domains: Data Products facilitate replication-free integration and consumption by SAP, customer, and partner applications via APIs and Events.
  2. Efficient Data Storage: Data Products are processed and curated in a modern object-store based data lake architecture with highly scalable Spark processing.
  3. High-Quality Metadata: Metadata includes business semantics and is accessible through directories like the Data Product Directory and ORD Aggregators, enhancing discoverability.
  4. Optimized for Analytics: Data sets are curated for intensive reads and consumed in a read-only fashion, ensuring efficiency and reliability.
  5. Supporting Analytical and AI Applications: Data Products provide foundational data for dashboards, analytical models, and AI applications.
  6. Decentralized Ownership: Inspired by Data Mesh principles, Data Products are owned and managed by domain experts or teams responsible for operational data.
  7. Lifecycle Management: Data Products undergo needs analysis, design, and delivery phases, ensuring their accuracy and relevance.

Types

A data product can be of the type:

  • Primary: A data product exposed for consumption directly from an application. It's likely not to have input ports.
  • Derived: A data product that aggregates and combines data from multiple sources to provide value-added data sets. Derived data products must provide at least one input port with an integration dependency with at least one requirement.

Categories

Based on the dataset associated with the data product, it can have the following categories:

  • Business objects: The dataset contains business objects of type master data and transactional data.
  • Analytical data: The dataset contains analytical data such as KPIs, cubes, and metrics.
  • Other: All other types of datasets such as configuration data, mixed, and so on.

What are Data Product Definition files?

 Data Product Definition files are structured artifacts that describe and encapsulate curated datasets‚Äîeither master or transactional data‚Äîdesigned for easy, secure, and reusable consumption across applications and domains. These files define the metadata, structure, and access interfaces of a data product.

These files are built using Open Resource Discovery (ORD) standards, ensuring consistency and interoperability.

Stored within Foundation Services, these definition files play a key role in discovering required data products.

As we continue our journey with SAP BDC we hope to discover more usage of Data products and how they can be utilized in the best way possible.

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in May
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in May

Another month with great new releases is in the books ‚ú®
We delivered great new features in SAP Datasphere with all May releases. Learn more in my short top features video in May 2025 on YouTube üì∫
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

My top features in May

 

Replication Flows

Reusing a Source Object in Several Replication Flows

You can now use a single source object in multiple replication flows. So far, the objects could only be used in one replication flow, but now this restriction was lifted and reusability is allowed. 
‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

SFTP as Target for Replication Flow

You can now create replication flows to replicate data from supported source systems into Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) targets with load types ‚Äòinitial only‚Äô and ‚Äòinitial and delta‚Äô with parquet, JSON and CSV files. 
‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Array support for Confluent Kafka as Source

For Confluent Kafka sources you can now expand arrays or maps when reading from Confluent topics. In the replication flow editor you can change the schema properties of an individual object with primary keys and custom opcode columns and values. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information.

 

Task Scheduling with shorter Increments

The new enhanced scheduling feature allows tasks to be set at 5-minute intervals, offering greater flexibility and precision in task management. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information.

 

Local Table Partitioning With Hash Partitioning

When creating your local table from the Data Builder you can define partitions based on one or several columns of your table to break your data down into smaller and more manageable parts. You can now choose between range partitioning or hash partitioning. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information.

 

 

SAPPHIRE

May covered two exceptional SAP SAPPHIRE events in Orlando and Madrid. We had great coverage with more than 30 sessions on SAP Business Data Cloud including SAP Datasphere by product managers, executives, customers, and partners covering all areas of BDC including roadmap sessions, demos, and strategy talks. Some of them have been recorded and can be accessed via the üîó SAP Business Data Cloud track on the session catalog.

 

More blogs to check out üëá

entry.title: Understanding ABAP Pipeline Engine used for Data Integration in Datasphere
entry.content:
Background:

This article would help in understanding how ABAP Pipeline engine aids data extraction process when you try to extract data from any S/4 HANA Table or a S/4 HANA CDS view which is Extraction and CDC Enabled CDS using a Replication flow of Datasphere with Initial Only and Initial + Delta options.

A Data-integration would be required to ingest the data from Source to a Target where an Advanced Analytics or Modelling or reporting would be performed.

In Data-extraction, there are two aspects

  • Full load (Initial Load only; One-off load)
  • Initial Load +Delta load.

Full Load: It is also called as Initial Load only or One-off load, where in the load will happen only once; post the load the delta records will not be flowing to the target.

Initial + Delta: It will first do a full load, post that the deltas will be pushed to the target based on the specified frequency.

How  SLT works:  Whenever we keep any table for replication it creates

  • Log Table ‚Äì A table is one which is meant to hold the delta records
  • Trigger ‚Äì Insert update and Delete triggers were created on top the base table in source; whenever any CRUD operation happened, respective triggers were invoked which in-turn ingests the data into the log table; based on the frequency set, these records from the log table were pushed to the target.

Similarly; in Datasphere, it uses ABAP Pipeline Engines (APE) which aids in achieving the two aspects of Data Integration mentioned above.

Either a direct table or an Extraction, CDC enabled CDS view can be used for data extraction. In the either of the cases the behavior is same.

Below screenshot from a standard CDS view I_CUSTOMER, in the CDC Mapping annotation, KNA1 is the primary table from which the delta is to be deduced.

In nutshell, if we keep either KNA1 table for replication or I_CUSTOMER for replication(which is based on KNA1) the behavior of APE will the same and both the cases the delta will be deduced with respect to KNA1.

ABAP Pipeline Engine(APE): Used for integrating and processing data from ABAP-based systems, such as SAP S/4HANA, within broader data workflows.

In this blog we shall see what happens when we use a Extraction CDC enabled CDS view for extraction generates below components of APE.

Scenario 1: Initial Load + Delta
When we extract an Extraction and CDC enabled CDS view using Replication flow of Datasphere, below components are generated.

  • Trigger creation : Whenever any table or CDS view is kept for replication, it creates Insert, Update and Delete triggers on the top of the table (or table which is defined in cdc mapping of  CDS view). Respective triggers are invoked in case of any insert, update or delete operations on the table.
  • Master Logging table: The master logging table is the single source of truth for this job to catch the triggers, i.e  its the first table which gets filled in once any of the triggers are triggered because of a CRUD operation.         
    • Naming convention-  /1DH/ML<XXXXXXXXX>     
    • Data Definition of a Master Logging Table:

  • Number of Master Logging table created is equal number of CDC mappings defined in the CDS view
  • In the below example two master Logging tables are created

If we check in DHCDCMON t-code, we can see that two Master and Subscriber logging tables are created

  • Subscriber Logging table:
    • Once there are records filled in the Master Logging table, a real time job /1DH/OBSERVE_LOGTAB is triggered, which ingests the data into the Subscriber logging table
    • Naming Convention- Same name as Master logging table. M replaced with S /1DH/SL<XXXXXXXXX>.
    • Data Definition
      • The structure is same as Master Logging table, but the key here are the key fields of the base table (on which the cdc mapping is defined)

  • Buffer Table:
    • DHRDBMON is the tcode in which we can see the buffer table name for the corresponding CDS view name.
    • Naming Convention /1DH/RDB<XXXXX>
    • Data Definition: This has same structure as the CDS view which we have to extract the data.
    • /1DH/SEQUENCE is the key
    • Once the records are ingested in the Subscriber logging table, real time job /1DH/CDS_PUSH_DELTA  is triggered, which ingests the records into the Buffer table by making a join back to the base table based on the keys and ingest the records in the buffer table which has as definition of CDS view.

  • Real Time Jobs:
    • /1DH/OBSERVE_LOGTAB is a standard real time job which gets auto triggered whenever there are records in Master Logging table. It reschedules itself for every 1hour (Default setting) to avoid coming into the list of long running jobs
    • /1DH/CDS_PUSH_DELTA is a standard real time job which is auto triggered whenever there are records in Subscriber Logging table. . It reschedules itself for every 6hours (Default setting) to avoid coming into the list of long running jobs
    • They can been seen in SM37, they run under DDIC user.

Example: Lets consider a Custom CDS view with Definition

Advantages:

We can create multiple Extraction CDC enabled CDS views with same source; when extracting data from these two CDS views using Datasphere with INIT + Delta option, the Trigger, Master and Subscriber logging table are common with subscribers. i.e two different buffer table will be created for the respective CDS views based on the fields that are selected in the CDS view projection.

Subscriber 1 and Subscriber 2: Refer to the two Extraction CDC Enabled CDS Views that are built using the same source and is kept for data extraction using Replication flow of Datasphere.

Scenario 2: Initial Load Only:

Whenever we extract data from a CDS view with INIT Only option in Datasphere, below artifacts are created.

A buffer table is created based on the structure of the CDS view used in Replication flow of Datasphere, from which the data is read by Datasphere.

Summary:

 

FeatureMaster Logging TableSubscriber Logging TableBuffer Table
Naming Convention/1DH/ML<XXXXXXXXX>   /1DH/SL<XXXXXXXXX>  /1DH/RDB<XXXXX>
Key/1DH/SEQUENCEKey of the base table/1DH/SEQUENCE 
Data FillGets filled from TriggersGets filled in once /1DH/LOGTAB is triggeredGets filled in once /1DH/CDS_PUSH_DELTA is triggered
Table MaintanenceRecords are deleted once the Subscriber logging table is filledRecords are delted once the Buffer table is filledRecords are deleted once the data is ingested to target
Table StructureHas the key fields of the base tableHas key fields of the base tableHas all the fields of the CDS view
TcodeDHCDCMONDHCDCMONDHRDBMON
Read by Datasphere  Datasphere accesses this table to ingest the data to target
Table GenrationOne of each table defined in CDC MappingOne of each table defined in CDC Mappingone per Extraction Enabled CDS view
Table GenrationNumber of Master logging table is equal
to the number CDC mapping defined in the CDS view		Number of Subscriber logging table is equal to the number CDC
 mapping defined in the CDS view		One Extraction Enabled CDS view is equal to one Buffer table
ScopeComes into picture only for INIT+Delta Comes into picture only for INIT+Delta Comes into picture for both Initial only and INIT+Delta

entry.title: Query modelling in SAP DATASPHERE with use case example
entry.content:
Manipulating queries in SAP Datasphere (formerly SAP Data Warehouse Cloud) involves working within its SQL-based modeling environment, graphical views, and business layer. Depending on your objective‚Äîtransforming data, filtering, joining, or creating calculated columns‚Äîhere are the primary ways to manipulate queries in Datasphere:

Here is a solution to how we can manipulate data with simple SQL queries that can be used to manipulate data results:

- Graphical View Modeling (No-Code/Low-Code)

SAP Datasphere offers a graphical modeling environment to build views (analytical, calculation, or relational). You can manipulate queries visually by:

  • Adding Filters: Apply filters on specific fields (e.g., Region = ‚ÄòUS‚Äô) in the semantics or projection nodes.
  • Creating Calculated Columns: Add new derived columns using formulas (like IF, CASE, arithmetic).
  • Joining Tables: Drag and connect tables using inner, left outer, or full joins.
  • Aggregating Data: Apply aggregation (e.g., SUM(Sales)) at group or table level.
  • Input Parameters & Variables: Add prompts for runtime filtering.
- SQL View Modeling (Code-Based) (Simple)

Datasphere supports SQL-based views using standard SQL and SQL extensions. Here's how you can manipulate queries programmatically:

a. Create Filters

SELECT * FROM SalesData

WHERE Region = 'APAC' AND Year = 2024;

b. Create Calculated Fields

SELECT OrderID, Quantity, UnitPrice, Quantity * UnitPrice AS Revenue

FROM Orders;

c. Joins

SELECT a.CustomerID, a.Name, b.SalesAmount

FROM Customers a

JOIN Sales b ON a.CustomerID = b.CustomerID;

d. Using Parameters

Define reusable SQL views that take input parameters:

SELECT * FROM Orders

WHERE OrderDate >= :StartDate AND OrderDate <= :EndDate;

You define parameters in the View Properties > Parameters section.

 

- Use Business Builder for Semantics (Deep Dive provided in the next section)

The Business Builder allows data modeling with business semantics:

Rename technical fields (e.g., MATNR ‚Üí Product ID)

Define hierarchies and associations

Build Consumption Models that serve as the final layer for analytics tools (like SAP Analytics Cloud)

 

- Manipulate Query Runtime Behavior

Use Variables: Define filters users can change at runtime (e.g., time ranges, cost centers)

Apply Restricted Measures: For example, filter a measure for a specific product group

Create Aggregation Levels: Define the level at which KPIs should roll up (e.g., by quarter, not month)

Example: Combine and Filter Customer & Sales Data

SELECT c.CustomerName, s.SalesAmount, s.Region

FROM Customers c

JOIN Sales s ON c.CustomerID = s.CustomerID

WHERE s.Region = 'Europe' AND s.Year = 2025;

You can turn this into a SQL View, then expose it via a Consumption Model with input parameters like Region and Year.

Step-by-Step Guide for a customer table example:

We assume two tables:

  • CUSTOMERS
CustomerID, CustomerName, Region
  • SALES
SalesID, CustomerID, Product, Quantity, UnitPrice, SalesDate

Step 1: Create a SQL View in Datasphere

  1. Go to Data Builder.
  2. Click Create ‚Üí SQL View.
  3. Name it SALES_ANALYSIS_VIEW.

Paste the SQL code:

Click Save and Deploy the view.

Step 2: Add Input Parameters (Optional)

  1. In the SQL View editor, click Parameters tab.
  2. Add parameter P_REGION (String).
  3. Modify SQL:
...

WHERE

    c.Region = :P_REGION

Now it's dynamic user can choose the region at runtime.

Step 3: Create a Business Layer Consumption Model

  1. Go to Business Builder.
  2. Click Create Consumption Model.
  3. Add the SQL View SALES_ANALYSIS_VIEW as the source.
  4. Configure:
    • Dimensions: CustomerName, Region, Product
    • Measures: Revenue
    • Add P_REGION as an input prompt
  5. Save and publish the model.

Step 4: Consume in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  1. Open SAC ‚Üí Create Story ‚Üí Use SAP Datasphere live connection.
  2. Choose your SALES_ANALYSIS_VIEW Consumption Model.
  3. SAC prompts for P_REGION ‚Üí select value like ‚ÄúNorth America‚Äù.
  4. Visualize:
    • Bar chart: Revenue by Product
    • Table: Revenue by Customer

How to Use the Business Builder in detail:

Open Business Builder (Logged into Datasphere- Needs license)

  • Go to Business Catalog ‚Üí Select Business Builder
  • Click Create ‚Üí Business Entity

Create Business Entities

  • Choose base view (Graphical or SQL View)
  • Map technical fields to business names
  • Define primary keys, descriptions, and labels

Create Associations

  • Example: In Sales Entity, associate CustomerID to the Customer Entity
  • You can now drill from Sales to Customer details in reports

Define Measures & Attributes

  • Add calculated fields (e.g., Revenue = Quantity * UnitPrice)
  • Define aggregation behavior (sum, count, etc.)

Build a Consumption Model

  • Combine entities like Customers, Sales, Products
  • Select fields for display
  • Add filters, input parameters (e.g., Region, Date Range)
  • Define KPIs like Total Sales, Average Order Value

Publish to Analytics

  • Once saved and deployed, Consumption Models appear in SAP Analytics Cloud
  • SAC users get clean, business-ready models with consistent logic

Business Builder Benefits:

Benefit

Explanation

Business Semantic Layer

Translates technical models into business terms

No SQL Needed

Drag-and-drop interface to build models

Reduced Complexity

Hide joins, filters, and calculated fields from end users

Security Enforcement

Add row-level or column-level access rules

Reusability

Share standard metrics (like KPIs) across models

Analytics Ready

Creates models ready for SAC, Excel, or external APIs

Final Thoughts:

Queries should be written in a good way such that the performance is not hampered. Every example is different and a common protocol cannot be followed for every single use case. 

Please work with subject matter experts to form high performance queries.

entry.title: All Datasphere Functions in One File
entry.content:
All Datasphere Functions in One File ‚Äì A Handy Resource for Consultants

Hi SAP Community! üëã

I wanted to share something I‚Äôve recently put together that might save you some time and effort, especially if you're working with SAP Datasphere and don't have access to Joule for Consultants.

During my work with graphical views, I realized how helpful it would be to have all the available functions in one place. So I created a File that contains the complete list of functions you can use in a graphical view transformation.

The file includes three simple columns:

  • ID ‚Äì A running number

  • Function Title ‚Äì The name of the function

  • Text ‚Äì An example of how to use it

You can use this file in several ways:

  • As a quick reference for transformations

  • To train a local GPT model 

  • To upload it to ChatGPT
    (If your organization allows access to the public version) and ask questions like ‚ÄúHow to obtain this value 20290506 when I have a May 6th, 2025 date column?

üí°Download the file in the link below

Note. To have it in Excel. Open Excel and drag and drop this .txt file there. Excel will separate the values in columns.

üëâHow to Set Up Joule For Consultants

entry.title: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions.

Learn more: SAP Business Data Cloud | SAP

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are core component services of BDC.  Both services remain strategic to SAP and will continue to be enhanced through their own roadmaps, offered via SAP Business Data Cloud.

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are scheduled to be removed from the list of Eligible Cloud Services for new BTPEA, CPEA, and PAYG subscriptions as of January 1, 2026.  

What does this mean for customers? 

These services will be available until the end of a customer‚Äôs current BTPEA, CPEA, or PAYG agreement terms.  After December 31, 2025, these services will not be available for renewal. While the services will not be available for renewal terms, the same services will continue to be available in SAP Business Data Cloud.

Existing BTPEA and CPEA customers who purchase cloud credits before January 1, 2026, will be able to continue to use their cloud credits for SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud for the duration of their agreements.

Although customers can continue their current BTPEA, CPEA, and PAYG agreements, there is no need to wait to move to SAP Business Data Cloud.  Customers can now begin their transition plans to SAP BDC.  Please contact your SAP Account team to support your plans.

Note: Existing SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud tenants will be preserved under SAP BDC, no technical migration required. 

 

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

entry.title: A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
entry.content:
Many developers have contacted me in message box asking how to start with learning SAP BDC.

SAP Has provided many learning paths for same which are available on the Learning hub, but, what about people who don‚Äôt have access to learning hub or someone who is still working in legacy technologies.

Sharing these learning links hoping that this will help atleast a few people who trying to learn SAP BDC.

 

Core Components of SAP BDC system

Layer

Description

Source Systems

Includes SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and external systems. Data is bundled into entities like tables and views for replication.

Foundation Services

Harmonizes and transforms raw data into Data Products. These are stored in a hyperscaler environment (SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake files).

SAP Datasphere

Acts as the semantic layer. Defines data models, manages access control, and supports both prebuilt and custom analytical scenarios.

SAP Databricks

Embedded AI/ML engine for advanced analytics. Enables pro-code engineering and machine learning extensions.

SAP Analytics Cloud

Provides visualization, planning, and ad-hoc analysis capabilities. Powers dashboards and intelligent applications.

BDC Cockpit

Central hub for managing Data Products, Intelligent Applications, and data sharing workflows.

 

You must learn SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics cloud to be ready for SAP BDC.

 

You may use below link to learn more about SAP Datasphere.

Get Started with Your Trial in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials

This mission is the ideal starting point for newcomers to start using SAP Datasphere, get their trial account, and learn the fundamentals for modelling their data in SAP Datasphere.

This training will cover below activities.

  1. Get to Know the SAP Datasphere Interface | SAP Tutorials : talks about how to navigate the user interface of SAP Datasphere and what the home screen controls can do for you
  2. Add Users and Assign Roles in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to add users into your SAP Datasphere tenant, how to assign roles to users, How to edit users in bulk
  3. Create and Monitor a Space in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to create a Space and how to manage and monitor your Space
  4. Create an Entity Relationship Model in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about overview of E/R Models, how to create an E/R Model, how to associate data columns and how to finalise an E/R Model and deploy
  5. Create a Graphical View in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : talks about graphical views, how to create them, how to rename and restore columns in Graphical view and their deployment
  6. Define Measures and Add Business Information to a View | SAP Tutorials talks about what is semantic information, how to define measures, how to add business information, how to change business names of measures and attributes, how to change the semantic type of measures and attributes and how to preview your modelled dataset
  7. Generate Time Table and Dimensions | SAP Tutorials talks about how to create time tables and dimensions and how to associate the time dimensions with your data
  8. Upload Flat Files and Wrangle Your Data | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to upload flat files in the Data Builder of SAP Datasphere, how to make the best of the Data Builder capabilities during a file upload process and how to transform the data for data consistency and integrity
  9. Replicate Data into SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to check the type of data access, how to create a real time data replication and how to schedule the data replication
  10. Integrate and Monitor Data with SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to access the Data Integration Monitor, how to use the Data Integration Monitor dashboard and the types of monitoring you can do with the Data Integration Monitor

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in June
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in June

Another month with a great new release delivery ‚ú®
Learn more in my short top features video in June 2025 on YouTube üì∫
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in June

 

SQL and Script Views as Source Objects for Your Replication Flows

You can create a replication flow with an SQL view or a script view as a source. Supported connections are SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA On-premise and SAP Datasphere. Initial only loads are currently supported, and you must define a primary key for your view to allow the deployment. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Python Version 3.11 available for Data Flows

The Data Flow script operator enables the Python version 3.11 for your data flows. When creating a data flow or modifying an existing one, you can now choose the new Python Version 3.11. Please note that Python 3.9 will reach its end-of-life soon, hence we recommend upgrading your data flows to 3.11 as the maintenance for 3.9 ends in October 2025. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

New Data Types Supported for Local Tables (File)

We now support additional data types for local tables in the file space on the object store. You can now select the additional data types: DateTime, hana.BINARY and hana.TINYINT. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Object Store API calls

We separated API request calls from the compute in the flexible tenant configuration. That means you can now specify the number of API requests separately when configuring object storage. With the new option, you can define the expected number of API calls per month, giving you more control and accuracy in estimating your object storage needs. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

 

My favorite blog in June

There is an excellent blog I want you to be aware of. My friend and co-author of multiple books @FrankRiesner wrote this blog about SAP BW PCE and explains what it is, and also what it is not.

entry.title: Automating Flat File Loads in SAP Datasphere Using Generic SFTP Connections
entry.content:
With Datasphere release 2025.11, SAP introduced a powerful new feature: the Generic SFTP Connection. This enhancement significantly simplifies and automates the process of loading flat files into Datasphere.
Traditionally, users had to manually upload each flat file, which was cumbersome especially when dealing with multiple files. Now, with Generic SFTP, the process can be fully automated using scripting (e.g., Python), resulting in faster and more efficient bulk data ingestion.

This blog walks you through a basic method to leverage the Generic SFTP connection as a source object in a Data Flow. File formats currently supported include:JSON, JSONL, CSV, XLS, XLSX, ORC, and PARQUET.

Key Benefits

  • Automates repetitive flat file loads
  • Supports bulk data ingestion
  • Can be orchestrated using SAP Integration Suite or custom scripts (e.g., Python)

Prerequisites

  1. Valid Generic SFTP Connection
  2. Source File Availability

Steps to Load Data from Generic SFTP

First, you need to create a Data Flow to handle how the data will be ingested when transferred to generic SFTP

  • Go to the "Sources" tab in the Data Builder. Expand the "Connections" folder, navigate to the SFTP connection, and select the folder containing the source file.

 

  • Drag and drop the file onto the canvas.
  • (Optional) Click "Modify" to edit columns if needed. You can rename, remove, or change data types.

  • Click the source node and choose "Add Table" to create a new target table.
  • Click "Create and Deploy Table".
  • Choose the appropriate load Mode:
    • Append ‚Äì Add new records to existing data
    • Truncate ‚Äì Clear existing data before loading
    • Delete ‚Äì Remove existing records based on matching keys before loading
  • Run the Data Flow to load data into the target table.

Example Use Case: Automating Product Image Integration

Our organization leveraged the Generic SFTP Connections feature in SAP Datasphere to automate the integration of product image data into Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Here's how the solution was implemented:

  • A third-party system generates a flat file containing Product IDs and corresponding image URLs every time a new product is added.
  • For the initial load, we used a Python script to transfer this file to the SFTP server. A Dataflow configured in Append mode then loaded the file into a target table in Datasphere.
  • To incorporate the image URLs into the data model, we extended the Product Master Data dimension in Datasphere by adding a new attribute for the image URL. The semantic type of this attribute was set to "Image URL".
  • This enhancement allowed seamless integration into existing SAC dashboards, enabling dynamic display of product images.
  • For ongoing daily updates, we scheduled the Dataflow to run automatically. SAP Integration Suite transfers the updated file to the same SFTP folder each day, using a consistent file name to support full automation.

End result

# Generic script to transfer file to SFTP Server
# Be sure to change the source file and destination folder name
import paramiko
import os
# === SFTP connection details ===
hostname = <enter SFTP host> 
port = 22  # Usually 22 for SFTP
username = <enter user name> 
password = <Enter password> 
# === Local file and remote folder ===
local_file_path = < Source File name with Path> 
remote_folder_path = <Target Destination>    # No filename, just the folder

def upload_file_sftp():
   try:
       # Extract just the filename
       filename = os.path.basename(local_file_path)
       remote_file_path = os.path.join(remote_folder_path, filename).replace('\\', '/')

       # Connect to SFTP
       transport = paramiko.Transport((hostname, port))
       transport.banner_timeout = 10  # Prevent timeout errors
       transport.connect(username=username, password=password)

       sftp = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)

       # Upload the file
       print(f"Uploading {local_file_path} to {remote_file_path}")
       sftp.put(local_file_path, remote_file_path)
       print("Upload successful.")
       sftp.close()
   transport.close()

   except Exception as e:
       print(f"Error occurred: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
   upload_file_sftp()

Conclusion

This new feature drastically streamlined data ingestion pipelines and reduced manual effort for teams managing frequent flat file loads. By combining Datasphere‚Äôs Generic SFTP connections with automation scripts, organizations can achieve fully managed and scalable data pipelines

entry.title: The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend ‚Äì Part 1/3
entry.content:
Introduction

For many business users in finance and controlling, Microsoft Excel is more than just software ‚Äî it‚Äôs the daily tool for analysis, reporting, and, above all, corporate planning. Its flexibility and familiar environment are unbeatable. But how do you combine this flexibility with the power, security, and scalability of a central planning platform like the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?

The answer is the SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in for Microsoft Office. This modern add-in is positioned as the strategic successor to the proven SAP Analysis for Office, bridging the gap between the familiar world of Excel and the powerful in-memory planning engine of SAC.

A Quick Comparison: Analysis for Office vs. SAC Add-in

For anyone who has worked with SAP data in Excel for years, SAP Analysis for Office (AfO) is an old friend. It‚Äôs a robust and feature-rich tool, primarily designed for analyzing data from SAP BW and S/4HANA. It is based on traditional COM add-in technology and is heavily focused on querying BEx Queries or CDS Views.

The new SAC Add-in, on the other hand, was built from the ground up as a native frontend for the SAP Analytics Cloud. Here are the key differences and advantages at a glance:

  • Architecture: The SAC add-in is a modern Microsoft Office 365 add-in (based on WebView2). This allows for centralized, cloud-based deployment and management directly from the Microsoft Admin Center‚Äîwithout cumbersome client installations.
  • Connectivity: While AfO connects directly to backend systems like SAP BW, the primary and sole anchor point for the SAC add-in is your SAC tenant. All data, models, and permissions are sourced centrally from SAC.
  • Focus on Planning: The add-in is optimized for SAC planning models. Features like data entry, running data actions, version management, and using planning features are seamlessly integrated. You work in Excel but leverage the full power of the SAC planning engine in the background.
  • Future Strategy: SAP is clearly positioning the SAC add-in as the strategic tool for Excel integration in the cloud world.

The Architecture: Native Planning and ‚ÄûSeamless Integration‚Äú into Datasphere

The true strength of the new approach lies in its seamless architecture. Instead of keeping planning data in separate silos, SAC allows for direct integration with SAP Datasphere.

This concept ensures that planning data entered in Excel via the SAC add-in can be written directly into the underlying structures of SAP Datasphere. The data flow remains consistent and is always controlled by SAC.

Architecture Diagram: Planning with the SAC Add-in
Architecture

Building an Interactive Planning Sheet

A simple data table is just the beginning, but the true strength of the add-in lies in the combination of SAC data and the flexibility of Excel. Our goal is not just to display data, but to design an interactive planning input screen.

1. Define a Clear Layout:

Using the ‚ÄûBuilder‚Äú panel, drag the required dimensions into the rows and columns.

 

2. Use Excel Formulas for Ad-Hoc Analysis:

This is the key advantage: you can use native Excel formulas right next to the data loaded from SAC. For example, add a sum column and calculate it with a simple formula like =SUM(C7:E7). This cell updates dynamically as soon as new plan data is entered or changed.

 

3. Add Data Action Triggers:

Currently the excel add in supports triggering Data Actions directly (Multi Actions are planned for Q4 2025).

 

 

That‚Äôs it for the first part of this blog series, stay tuned for more advanced/technical content in the next blog post.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere introduced in 2023 advanced catalog functions aimed at making data more accessible and enhancing data-driven insights (initial announcement). This capability enables the management, organization and augmentation of metadata extracted from multiple SAP data sources. It aids in the discovery of curated data assets and lets users and data stewards search for and classify these assets. Additionally, the catalog allows to enhance assets with business metadata, supporting organizations in their data governance initiatives. Initially, it integrates with sources like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere BW Bridge (feature overview), pulling metadata from various assets within these systems.

SAP BW/4HANA as a comprehensive data warehouse enriched with massive content of business logic and semantics is a crucial element for our customers to unlock the full potential of advanced analytics, machine learning and informed decision-making at scale.

We are very happy today to announce that we are expanding the coverage of SAP Datasphere catalog metadata harvesting with the support of SAP BW/4HANA allowing our customers to run accurate, contextualized, and trustworthy data analysis.

Configuring Connection to SAP BW/4HANA

‚ÄãFirst let‚Äôs have a look at how we configure SAP Datasphere to connect and retrieve metadata from a SAP BW/4HANA system. This will require to create a live connection as well as reuse this live connection to create a remote system connection entry point for the catalog. Let's start by creating the live connection.

Click System and then Configuration.

In the Data Integration tab, you need to create a live data connection of type tunnel to the SAP BW/4HANA system to import the assets metadata. This live connection can be further reused either in Space Management to import models in modeller or in the remote systems for the metadata extractions for the catalog.

Click "Manage Live Data Connections".

Click "+" to create a new live connection, this will guide you to create this connection with a wizard-like experience.

This will require to fill in the following mandatory information:

  • Host URL
  • HTTPS Port
  • Client Id
  • User Name and Password

Once this live connection is created, we can now directly use it to create a remote system for the purpose of metadata harvesting.

Let's click on Catalog & Marketplace and then Metadata Extractions.

Click "+" to create a new remote system.

And now select the newly introduced entry "SAP BW/4HANA"

Select the Live Connection you just created before and then create this new remote connection.

Now we can edit the remote connection you just created to specify which Info Areas and sub info areas we want harvest the metadata from.

You can also switch to the Source Systems for information to see which source systems are involved in the retrieved metadata.

From then, we can synchronize the extraction of the metadata or define a scheduling job as usual with any of the remote systems the SAP Datasphere catalog can connect to.

The metadata for all the objects associated to the selected Info Areas will be available in the catalog. This includes the following type of containers or assets:

  • Info Areas
  • Source Systems
  • Advanced Datastore Objects
  • Info Objects
  • Data Source
  • Info Sources
  • Composite Providers
  • Transformations
  • BW Query Elements
  • Open ODS Views
  • Open Hub Destinations
  • Data Transfer Processes
  • Aggregation Levels

Exploring SAP BW/4HANA metadata

We can now explore the metadata available in the catalog from the BW/4HANA system we synced with by clicking "Catalog & Marketplace" and then "Search".

We can select the container that corresponds to our BW/4HANA system we harvested the metadata from.

And then expand and navigate through the different Info Areas or Source Systems as containers.

You can also filter by the different types of assets available

Click "Show More" to see the entire list of supported objects that can help you refine what you are searching for.

Opening any of the asset gives access to the technical metadata as well as the column details. Any of the existing feature to enrich the assets with business metadata such as descriptions, business glossary terms, KPIs, and Classification Tags can be used to further enhance the metadata for the SAP BW/4HANA harvested metadata as described in this blog.

Lineage and Impact Analysis graph is available for any of the assets from BW/4HANA when applicable which allows to understand how the objects are created and how they are used, but also offers easy navigation to other assets in the catalog.

By leveraging SAP Datasphere catalog with metadata harvested from SAP BW/4HANA, organizations can ensure that their data is not only accessible but also meaningful and reliable, driving informed decision-making and powering advanced analytics and AI initiatives.

What‚Äôs Next?

We will continue to extend the coverage of the SAP metadata we can harvest to continuously support organizations on their data governance journey.

I also want to share some additional resources for you around SAP Datasphere: 

  • Join SAP Datasphere community to see what‚Äôs new, ask questions, share your feedback, and more. 
  • SAP Datasphere product overview  
  • Documentation for SAP Datasphere catalog

entry.title: SAP BDC Ecosystem
entry.content:
By now you may have got a good understanding of SAP BDC components from my earlier blogs.

Now let's try to see how it all fits together.

 

 

At the first level we start with the data repository source. It may be an SAP system (like SAP S/4, Success Factor, SAP BW etc. )  or any non-SAP system.

Customers struggle a lot in heterogeneous system where data is stored in multiple different data storage systems. This data is vital for reporting.

 

For the data-driven modern organisations, having convenient access to all the necessary data in a specific and centralised location is important. Easy, convenient access ensures that data resources are always available at a moment‚Äôs notice, easing the process for you and allowing you to conduct all operations. 

 

With SAP BDC, various in-built SAP provided connectors available which we can use to connect to SAP as well as non-SAP systems and integrate them as a source of information i.e. transactional & master data.

SAP BDC system resides in SAP BTP platform similar to SAP Datasphere tenant sub-accounts currently. 

You will have a separate SAP Datasphere instance inside your SAP BDC environment.

SAP Datasphere is the evolution of the SAP data warehouse(earlier SAP BW) solution in the cloud, combining capabilities from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud with its agile enterprise data warehouse, self-service data modelling and SAP Data Intelligence Cloud with its data orchestration, lineage, quality, among other capabilities.

In data integration projects, a lot of time is spent trying to recreate context that has been lost during data replication, especially when getting data from the database layer belonging to heterogeneous storage systems.

With SAP BDC, customers will be able to bring all the structured and non-structured data under single umbrella in business data fabric.

This simplifies complex data landscapes and delivers meaningful data to every data consumer, be it Data architect, business user or a decision maker ‚Äì it takes the benefits and value further by keeping the business logic and application context from data intact.

For each of the source systems, SAP has provided ready-to-use data products which can be found in SAP BDC Cockpit.

To use out-of-the-box Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud with third-party data, first browse the available Data Products in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Then select and install the one that best meets your requirements before proceeding with integration.

 

 

 

 SAP BDC system eliminates the need to recreate all the business context lost from extracting data - giving business stakeholders and data consumers the ability to accelerate their decision-making with trust and confidence, knowing they always have the complete picture of their data regardless of where it is stored or how it was designed.

 

SAP Data products are combination of curated views & tables, metadata, access control, inbound and outbound interfaces, load capabilities, data lineage etc. which are used by semantic layer in SAP Datasphere by consumption ready data models which can be then used for internal data manipulation and transformation.

 

This data can then be used for

  1. Reporting by SAP Analytics cloud through live data, dashboards and stories
  2. AI/ML capabilities by Databricks for powerful compute and advance analytics
  3. Visualization by intelligent apps for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively

 

SAP BDC replicates source data into Datasphere object store once; downstream consumers access it from there.

With use of delta Sharing , Databricks gets real-time access to data without duplication saving storage space and associated costs.

 

 

 

All in all, SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality.

  • SAP BDC combines SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and their capabilities into one fully managed SaaS solution for all data and analytics needs.
  • It seamlessly integrates mission-critical SAP data with third-party sources‚Äîwithout losing business context or requiring constant extraction.
  • SAP transforms and harmonizes business data within a hyperscaler environment, ensuring high-quality, ready-to-use data across the board.
  • Prebuilt SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications deliver instant, AI-powered business insights with minimal setup, accelerating decision-making and innovation.

 

Ultimately, SAP BDC helps organizations:

  • Streamline operations with advanced data pipelines
  • Accelerate innovation through AI and predictive analytics
  • Improve agility by enabling teams to respond to change quickly
  • Drive business growth by turning data into a competitive advantage

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

entry.title: Tim Koster
entry.content:
Tim

  • Netherlands

Tim has been deeply involved with SAP Datasphere since its early days as SAP Data Warehouse Cloud, working directly with SAP Product Management teams to influence the product roadmap at some of Europe's largest implementations. He co-hosts the Dutch BI Podcast and is a frequent speaker at SAP events throughout the Netherlands, including SITnl, VNSG, and SAP Innovation Day. Tim actively contributes to the SAP Community through blogs and discussions and has developed tools for the SAP Datasphere community.

Topics of interest: SAP Datasphere, SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Databricks, AI within the SAP ecosystem

Tim, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Working with SAP Datasphere over the years, I've had the opportunity to collaborate with Product Management teams and contribute to various discussions around product development. These experiences have shown me how valuable it is when the community and SAP work together to shape solutions that truly meet customer needs. The SAP Mentor program feels like a natural next step to deepen this collaboration.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Share your real-world experiences - both successes and challenges. The community learns most from authentic stories. Engage directly with Product Management through forums, events, and feedback channels. Your voice as a practitioner matters immensely.

Stay curious about emerging technologies. The SAP landscape is evolving rapidly. Most importantly, contribute in whatever way feels authentic to you - whether it's writing blogs, speaking at events, or asking thoughtful questions in forums. Get involved, exchange ideas with other SAP professionals, and learn from different approaches. This collaborative learning makes us all better.

entry.title: BW-Like Authorizations in Datasphere (DSP)
entry.content:
Basics:
In DSP, authorizations are managed at the space level, not for individual Data Builder objects like in BW (e.g., InfoCubes (RSINFOCUBE), InfoObjects (RSIOBJNM), ‚Ä¶). Privileges grant access to specific tasks (creating Data Builder objects, translations, running flows, etc.), but not to individual flows or objects themselves.

While privileges can restrict access to unexposed views within a space, developers (with the "modeler" role) retain access. Therefore, this access control method is only effective in Test/Production systems. For exposed views or Analytical Models, you must implement Data Access Control (DACs).

Application Component, InfoArea, Cube/Composite, ADSO, InfoObject, ‚Ä¶:

Simulating InfoArea RSINFOAREA or specific Provider RSINFOCUBE, RSIOBJNM in a space is not possible without high development and maintenance costs. One should create spaces for each Info Area and provide full access to all objects in a space.  (Architectural Proposal/suggestion details in this blog:  https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030)

Possible work around would be:

  • Create DAC: User to DSP / Builder Object.
  • Mandatory usage of the DAC in each persisted Object (persistency constraint).
  • DAC tables must be maintained in a different space (to avoid developers changing the authorizations).
  • Developers must not have Data Warehouse Data Access Control Privilege assigned.
  • Each DAC relevant / Builder object would have to have the Security Field included.

However, con is very high maintenance costs. Therefore: RSINFOAREA, RSAPPLNM, RSINFOCUBE/S_RS_HCPR, RSIOBJNM, ‚Ä¶ should be replaced with access to a specific InfoArea-like Space.

RSZCOMPTP / Query:

cannot be done in DSP at all. Exposed Views or AMs are consumed in SAC as Stories or Applications (or 3rd party tools, this blog describes SAC only).

In SAC the Teams would be our entry point simulating the InfoArea, Cube/Composite access. Teams allow access to specific Folders, Stories, Applications and group SAC Roles providing permissions for specific tasks / objects.

In case the SAC is used like Query-Designer, without Planning features, the setup is straightforward. Just create a Team for each InfoArea allowing the users to execute the Stories.

 BIAUTH / Data Authorizations:

  • Authorization data must be transferred to DACs.  Example: 0PLANT, 0COMP_CODE (this can be done automatically from BW/4: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-remote-authorizations-from-sap-bw-4hana-for-sap-datasphere/ba-p/13518819 (DSP already allows wildcards and hierarchy nodes). 
  • Alternative is to download the data manually into CSVs und use the CSVs as basis to the DAC tables.
  • Assign the DACs into model-views/AMs and thus protect the data.

If you follow the central space approach, where data persistency is done in the central space and the InfoArea-like space just consumes shared views, you can implement DACs in every Builder object.

entry.title: Session 5 Recap & Highlights - Planning Your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's review the key insights from our session on 'Planning your transition path to SAP Business Data Cloud'.

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) marks a transformative approach to enterprise data management and utilization. This comprehensive SaaS platform centralizes and governs SAP data assets while integrating effortlessly with external data sources. BDC is designed to tackle the increasing complexity of today's data environments and meet the critical demand for AI-enabled, real-time analytical capabilities.

 

Customer Needs Driving the Transition

Organizations face several critical challenges that SAP BDC is designed to address:
Data Accessibility and Context: Companies struggle with extracting data from SAP systems while maintaining business semantics and context. When data is moved to external platforms, valuable business meaning is often lost, requiring significant time and resources to rebuild .

AI and Analytics Acceleration: Modern businesses need high-quality, AI-ready data to drive reliable and accurate artificial intelligence applications. The traditional approach of fragmented data silos impedes innovation and limits the potential for advanced analytics .

Simplified Data Landscape: Multiple tools, manual processes, and inconsistent data preparation tasks slow the development of advanced analytics and AI capabilities. Organizations seek a unified platform that can eliminate these inefficiencies.

Real-time Insights: The demand for faster time-to-insights requires modern infrastructure capable of supporting real-time decision-making processes across all business functions.

 

Adoption Journey and Transition Approaches
SAP has defined a structured approach to BDC adoption that allows organizations to progress at their own pace while preserving existing investments. The transition follows a three-phase methodology: Lift, Shift, and Innovate.

 

Evolving Beyond SAP Data and Analytics Portfolio

SAP customers utilizing systems like SAP BW (Business Warehouse), SAP HANA, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud are increasingly seeking pathways to modernize their data environments. The introduction of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) represents a major shift, offering organizations an integrated, cloud-native platform capable of unifying data from SAP and non-SAP sources, enabling advanced analytics, and powering AI-driven insights in real time.

Migrating from SAP BW and SAP HANA
Many enterprises have long relied on SAP BW for critical reporting and data warehousing needs. However, with SAP BW 7.5 reaching end of mainstream maintenance in 2027, businesses are tasked with deciding between maintaining aging systems or embracing cloud-ready solutions. BDC allows organizations to lift and shift their existing BW environments‚Äîincluding critical data models and business logic‚Äîdirectly into the cloud, often through SAP BW/4HANA private cloud edition. This preserves past investments while immediately unlocking scalable data products, improved governance, and seamless integration with SAP Datasphere and Databricks for analytics and AI scenarios. SAP HANA customers similarly benefit from BDC‚Äôs cloud-native architecture, which supports both structured and unstructured data, and offers scalable compute and flexible storage options for modern workloads.
 

 

Transitioning from SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud
With SAP BDC, customers currently operating SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud can expect a smooth, phased transition. BDC unifies these solutions into a single environment, streamlining workflows and reducing silos. Organizations leverage their existing data pipelines and analytics use cases - with features like zero-copy integration and data product generators - while quickly gaining access to enhanced AI, collaboration tools, and cross-platform interoperability. This means existing assets and semantic models in SAP Datasphere or Analytics Cloud can be retained and enriched rather than rebuilt, simplifying governance and accelerating time to value.
 
 
Key Benefits and Approach
The move to SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to minimize disruption. SAP provides a structured, stepwise migration methodology focused on:
  • Data Continuity: Preserving historical data and business rule integrity.
  • Operational Stability: Supporting parallel operations and robust fallback options during migration.
  • Capability Development: Offering training and resources so teams can maximize the value of BDC features.
  • Unified Data Governance: Centralizing oversight and compliance across all SAP and external data sources.

 

Strategic Planning Resources

It provides clear, concise answers to the most common technical and strategic questions architects encounter, such as how BDC unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, supports semantic modeling, and aligns with existing SAP environments like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP BW.

It provides a centralized platform where architects can explore missions, reference architectures, and best practice guides tailored to the unique challenges of data platform modernization. Through curated use cases and real-world implementation patterns, the Discovery Center clarifies how SAP BDC unifies SAP and non-SAP data, streamlines data integration, and supports advanced analytics and AI. Architects can leverage solution diagrams, architecture blueprints, and tools in the Discovery Center to design resilient, scalable BDC environments.

The SAP Architecture Centre is a strategic hub for enterprise architects navigating the transition to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). It offers in-depth reference architectures, solution diagrams, and best practice guides specifically designed to address the complex requirements of modern data management and cloud adoption.

 

Implementation Support

The Accelerator Hub offers immediate access to an extensive library of ready-to-use integration components, APIs, and architectural templates that simplify the creation and deployment of cloud data solutions designed for SAP's dynamic platform ecosystem. This centralized resource enables architects to rapidly identify, assess, and test APIs along with Data Product and Data Package elements specifically for S/4HANA Private Cloud environments, significantly reducing the challenges commonly encountered during cloud migration and hybrid integration projects.
 

 

The SAP Roadmap Explorer is a powerful tool that helps enterprise architects plan their transition to SAP Business Data Cloud with greater clarity and confidence. It provides a clear view of current features and future innovations related to BDC, allowing architects to understand what‚Äôs available now and what‚Äôs coming soon. This helps them align technical plans with business goals and make informed decisions about timing, dependencies, and integration points. Overall, the SAP Roadmap Explorer gives architects the insight they need to design a well-structured, future-ready path to SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

Technology Capability Model in LeanIX

 

LeanIX‚Äôs Technology Capability Model (TCM) provides a framework for:
  • Current state assessment of existing technology landscapes
  • Target architecture design for future state planning
  • Transformation roadmap development with clear milestones and dependencies
  • Governance structure establishment for implementation oversight

 

Next Steps and Way Forward
Immediate Actions
1. Assess current SAP BW environment using SAP‚Äôs free assessment service (SAP Migration Assessment)
2. Evaluate transition readiness through the BDC Discovery Workshop
3. Develop stakeholder alignment across business and IT teams
Medium-term Planning
1. Design target architecture using LeanIX and SAP Architecture Center resources
2. Create detailed migration roadmap with phased approach
3. Establish governance framework for ongoing transformation management
Long-term Vision
1. Implement AI/ML capabilities through Databricks integration
2. Adopt Intelligent Applications for accelerated business value
3. Optimize data product economy for reusable, scalable data assets

The transition to SAP Business Data Cloud represents more than a technical migration - it‚Äôs a strategic transformation that positions organizations for the AI-driven future of business. With SAP‚Äôs structured approach of Land, Expand, and Adopt, organizations can preserve existing investments while gaining access to cutting-edge capabilities. The comprehensive ecosystem of resources, tools, and professional services ensures that organizations have the support needed to navigate this critical transformation successfully.
With proper planning, stakeholder alignment, and strategic execution, the move to SAP Business Data Cloud can unlock significant business value and competitive advantage in an increasingly data-driven marketplace.
 

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link - Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey ‚Äì From Data to Intelligence!

entry.title: New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Upon the release of the Q2 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud Content and SAP Datasphere Content package, a new page has been added to the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story that is entirely dedicated towards SAP Fieldglass KPIs. This is the first of many updates to the tool that will expand its functionality far beyond SAP Ariba Procurement, allowing companies to analyze spend at a wider visibility than ever before.

The new page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement provides a big picture summary of SAP Fieldglass spend categories. Just like the other stories, users are presented with a clean and simplified view of data from select KPIs. Companies that choose to operationalize this new page may easily gain insights on their SAP Fieldglass data, including:

  • The influence of workforce management efficiency on overall revenue
  • Costs incurred by ensuring projects & hiring processes stay compliant
  • The financial impact of maintaining a quality workforce

If providing users with a way to further operationalize SAP Fieldglass data in a comprehensive analysis of spend piques your interest, please continue reading for more information on how to activate the new SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement.

1. SAP Analytics Cloud - Strategic Spend Overview

After opening the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story in SAP Analytics Cloud, navigate to the page entitled ‚ÄúFieldglass‚Äù. Along with the title, the top module contains a summary of spend related to high-value KPIs in SAP Fieldglass. A dimension module with a "Date Range" filtering option appears below the title module, followed by three data visualization modules, entitled ‚ÄúCost Savings‚Äù, ‚ÄúCompliance‚Äù, and ‚ÄúProcess Improvement‚Äù to represent the major categories of Fieldglass Transactions.

SAP Fieldglass page view in SAP Analytics Cloud

2. SAP Datasphere Integration for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement

Initiating the activation of the SAP Fieldglass page requires some manual configuration. After the necessary reports are built in Fieldglass, the user must download them in CSV format and upload them into SAP Datasphere. All other relevant objects can be found in the SAP_CONTENT space.

As of Q2 2025, the images below are the most updated views of the integration architecture and the SAP Datasphere objects included in the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement package.

Integration architecture (updated to include SAP Fieldglass assets)

SAP Datasphere objects view (updated to Include SAP Fieldglass objects)

As a reminder, the following naming conventions have been used:
SM -> Supplier Management
SC -> Sourcing & Contracts
BI -> Buying & Invoicing
FG -> Fieldglass

The data modeling for the SAP Fieldglass page follows the layered approach of content development in SAP Datasphere. Here, the set up for SAP Fieldglass Project analysis is used as the example, the photo below describing the direction of the model layers:

SAP Fieldglass data model workflow

The Integration Layer (IL) contains the local table SAP Fieldglass: Project (LT) (SAP_Fieldglass_SRC_Project_MA), which was created in a manual file upload, as mentioned previously. In addition, this layer also includes the abstracting view, SAP Fieldglass: Project (IL) (SAP_PROC_FG_IL_Project), which adds data specific to the realm.

The Harmonization Layer (HL), SAP Fieldglass: Project (HL) (SAP_PROC_FG_HL_ProjectSQL), acts as the Fact View that combines Fieldglass project data with the Date Grid view.

Finally, the Reporting Layer (RL) uses the Analytic Model SAP Fieldglass: Project (RL) (SAP_PROC_FG_RL_Project) to define additional calculated measures and expose the data to the SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Analytics Cloud.

3. Content Documentation

Thank you for reading this SAP Community article!

To view the blog post on the original release of SAP Value Analytics for SAP Ariba Procurement in Q2 2024, please view ‚ÄòMaximize Value with Value Analytics for SAP Ariba‚Äô by @SimonKranig.

For further instructions on configuring SAP Value Analytics for Procurement, please view this discovery mission.

More details on the SAP Fieldglass content package for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement can be found on this SAP Help page.

Have questions and want to share with other users? Feel free to post a question in the community:
SAP Community > SAP Analytics Cloud
SAP Community > SAP Datasphere
